He's a social conservative who has talked of ending France's famed   work week and getting tough with the country's powerful trade unions. He has also spoken of cutting public spending, abolishing the wealth tax, reducing immigration and investing billions in security, defense and justice.
Fillon plans to slash public spending by 100 billion euros over five years, scrap a tax on the wealthy and push the retirement age to 65 as well as increase VAT sales tax. "It's a program of chaos.
The battle will largely focus on economic policy. Fillon has promised a "radical shock" for France with   reform, major cuts to public sector jobs and reducing public spending.

A hard line on immigration has also bolstered Le Pen, whose   stance is gaining popularity among French voters. In an interview with CNN last week, she said she'd been emboldened by Donald Trump's surprise victory in the United States.

His traditionalist and socially conservative line on family values and "the Christian roots of France" his emphasis on French national identity, "sovereignty" and "patriotism" his hard line on immigration and Islam as well as a   foreign agenda against "American imperialism" all overlap with some of Le Pen's key ideas.
Fillon also took a hard line against multiculturalism.
His prime minister, Manuel Valls, is more popular, but he's facing a challenge from Emmanuel Macron, a charismatic   and former economy minister who's running as an independent.
Fillon's main rival, Juppe, is also a former prime minister, under President Jacques Chirac.
But this doesn't mean it will be unduly easy for Fillon, a former prime minister who has spent 35 years in politics and is a figurehead of the   Catholic, provincial French right.

Despite Fillon's hardline rightwing stances, he is not a populist. "He's closer to [the former British prime minister] David Cameron than [the Ukip leader] Nigel Farage," said   Camus, an expert on the French far right.
But to do that, the   old former prime minister and admirer of late British prime minister Margaret Thatcher now faces the challenge of bringing voters behind a program that promises radical change.

He served in the cabinet five times, and as prime minister from 2007 to 2012. (In the French system, the prime minister generally plays second fiddle, helping to implement priorities set by the president.)
Regardless, Fillon became one of the premier critics of the French welfare state, arguing for a need to slash 500, 000 civil service jobs and cut spending by $116 billion in five years.
Le Pen's campaign director, David Rachline, has called Fillon's programme "economically insane" for wanting to slash 500, 000 public sector jobs.

Polls had him mostly in third place, but he apparently struck a popular tone in the country's fight against Islamic terrorism and ISIS after publishing a new book, "Beating Islamic Totalitarianism". The first round of the primary, on November 20, put Fillon well ahead, with 44. 1% of the vote. Juppe received 28. 6% and former President Nicolas Sarkozy came in third with 20.
Juppe said he would support Fillon's campaign and former president Nicolas Sarkozy also called for unity.
Juppe, the widely popular moderate, and former Fillon frenemy Sarkozy were the favorites in the primary, with polls between them narrowing as the campaign went on.

Fillon could face   National Front Party leader Marine Le Pen in the final round of the presidential vote next spring, as voters are widely expected to boot out the Socialist Party that has ruled France since 2012 under the leadership of President Francois Hollande, whose popularity is waning.
